dn2:0.2: The Fruits of the Ascetic Life
dn2:1.0: 1. A Discussion With the King’s Ministers
dn2:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Mango Grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 bhikkhus.
dn2:1.3: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the Komudī full moon on the fifteenth day of the fourth month—and King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, was sitting upstairs in the royal longhouse surrounded by his ministers.
dn2:1.4: Then Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, expressed this heartfelt sentiment,
dn2:1.5: “Oh, sirs, this moonlit night is so very delightful, so beautiful, so glorious, so pleasant, so striking.
dn2:1.6: Now, what ascetic or brahmin might I pay homage to today, paying homage to whom my mind might find peace?”
dn2:2.1: When he had spoken, one of the king’s ministers said to him,
dn2:2.2: “Sire, Pūraṇa Kassapa leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:2.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
dn2:2.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
dn2:2.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
dn2:3.1: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
dn2:3.2: “Sire, the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:3.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
dn2:3.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
dn2:3.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
dn2:4.1: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
dn2:4.2: “Sire, Ajita of the hair blanket leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:4.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
dn2:4.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
dn2:4.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
dn2:5.1: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
dn2:5.2: “Sire, Pakudha Kaccāyana leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:5.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
dn2:5.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
dn2:5.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
dn2:6.1: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
dn2:6.2: “Sire, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:6.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
dn2:6.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
dn2:6.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
dn2:7.1: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
dn2:7.2: “Sire, the Jain Nāṭaputta leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:7.3: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
dn2:7.4: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
dn2:7.5: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
dn2:8.1: Now at that time Jīvaka Komārabhacca was sitting silently not far from the king.
dn2:8.2: Then the king said to him,
dn2:8.3: “But my dear Jīvaka, why are you silent?”
dn2:8.4: “Sire, the Blessed One, the Arahant, the fully awakened Buddha is staying in my mango grove together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 bhikkhus.
dn2:8.6: ‘That Blessed One is an Arahant, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
dn2:8.7: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
dn2:8.8: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
dn2:8.9: “Well then, my dear Jīvaka, have the elephants readied.”
dn2:9.1: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Jīvaka. He had around five hundred female elephants readied, in addition to the king’s bull elephant for riding. Then he informed the king,
dn2:10.1: Then King Ajātasattu had women mounted on each of the five hundred female elephants, while he mounted his bull elephant. With attendants carrying torches, he set out in full royal pomp from Rājagaha to Jīvaka’s mango grove.
dn2:10.2: But as he drew near the mango grove, the king became frightened, scared, his hair standing on end.
dn2:10.4: “My dear Jīvaka, I hope you’re not deceiving me!
dn2:10.5: I hope you’re not betraying me!
dn2:10.6: I hope you’re not turning me over to my enemies!
dn2:10.7: For how on earth can there be no sound of coughing or clearing throats or any noise in such a large Saṅgha of 1,250 bhikkhus?”
dn2:10.8: “Do not fear, great king, do not fear!
dn2:10.11: or turning you over to your enemies.
dn2:10.12: Go forward, great king, go forward! Those are lamps shining in the pavilion.”
dn2:11.0: 3. The Question About the Fruits of the Ascetic Life
dn2:11.1: Then King Ajātasattu rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the pavilion door on foot, where he asked Jīvaka,
dn2:11.2: “But my dear Jīvaka, where is the Buddha?”
dn2:11.3: “That is the Buddha, great king, that is the Buddha!
dn2:11.4: He’s sitting against the central column facing east, in front of the Saṅgha of bhikkhus.”
dn2:12.1: Then the king went up to the Buddha and stood to one side.
dn2:12.2: He looked around the Saṅgha of bhikkhus, who were so very silent, like a still, clear lake, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment,
dn2:12.3: “May my son, Prince Udāyibhadda, be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of bhikkhus now enjoys!”
dn2:12.4: “Has your mind gone to one you love, great king?”
dn2:12.5: “Bhante, I love my son, Prince Udāyibhadda.
dn2:12.6: May he be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of bhikkhus now enjoys!”
dn2:13.1: Then the king bowed to the Buddha, raised his joined palms toward the Saṅgha, and sat down to one side.
dn2:13.3: “Sir, I’d like to ask you about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
dn2:14.1: “Sir, there are many different professional fields.
dn2:14.2: These include elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and sons of bondservants.
dn2:14.3: They also include bakers, barbers, bathroom attendants, cooks, garland-makers, dyers, weavers, basket-makers, potters, accountants, finger-talliers, or those following any similar professions. All these live off the fruits of their profession which are presently evident.
dn2:14.4: With that they make themselves happy and pleased. They make their parents, their children and partners, and their friends and colleagues happy and pleased. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.
dn2:14.5: Sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise presently evident?”
dn2:15.1: “Great king, do you recall having asked this question of other ascetics and brahmins?”
dn2:15.3: “If you wouldn’t mind, great king, tell me how they answered.”
dn2:15.4: “It’s no trouble when someone such as the Blessed One is sitting here.”
dn2:16.1: “One time, Bhante, I approached Pūraṇa Kassapa and exchanged pleasantries with him.
dn2:16.2: When the amicable and cordial talk was over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
dn2:17.2: ‘Great king, the one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do nothing wrong when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie. If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
dn2:17.3: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
dn2:17.4: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.
dn2:17.5: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’
dn2:18.1: And so, when I asked Pūraṇa Kassapa about the fruits of the ascetic life that are presently evident, he answered with the doctrine of inaction.
dn2:18.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
dn2:18.5: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
dn2:18.6: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Pūraṇa Kassapa.
dn2:18.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
dn2:19.0: 3.2. The Doctrine of the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla
dn2:19.1: One time, Bhante, I approached the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla and exchanged pleasantries with him.
dn2:19.2: When the amicable and cordial talk was over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
dn2:20.2: ‘Great king, there is no cause or reason for the defilement of beings. Beings are corrupted without cause or reason.
dn2:20.3: There’s no cause or reason for the purification of beings.
dn2:20.4: Beings are purified without cause or reason.
dn2:20.5: One does not act of one’s own volition, one does not act of another’s volition, one does not act from a person’s volition. There is no power, no effort, no human strength or vigor.
dn2:20.6: All beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.
dn2:20.7: There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600. There are 500 deeds, and five, and three. There are deeds and half-deeds. There are 62 paths, 62 sub-eons, six classes of birth, and eight stages in a person’s life. There are 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 naked ascetics. There are 2,000 faculties, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dust. There are seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, and seven knotless embryos. There are seven gods, seven humans, and seven goblins. There are seven lakes, seven rivers, 700 rivers, seven cliffs, and 700 cliffs. There are seven dreams and 700 dreams. There are 8.4 million great eons through which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering.
dn2:20.8: And here there is no such thing as this: “By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or renunciate life I shall force unripened deeds to bear their fruit, or eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little,” for that cannot be.
dn2:20.9: Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse.
dn2:20.10: It’s like how, when you toss a ball of string, it rolls away unraveling.
dn2:20.11: In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’
dn2:21.1: And so, when I asked the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla about the fruits of the ascetic life that are presently evident, he answered with the doctrine of purification through transmigration.
dn2:21.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
dn2:21.5: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
dn2:21.6: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla.
dn2:21.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
dn2:22.0: 3.3. The Doctrine of Ajita of the Hair Blanket
dn2:22.1: One time, Bhante, I approached Ajita of the hair blanket and exchanged pleasantries with him.
dn2:22.2: When the amicable and cordial talk was over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
dn2:23.2: ‘There’s no giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad actions. This world doesn’t exist, nor the other world. There is no mother or father, nor beings that reappear spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who, having comprehended and experienced it for himself, makes known this world and the other.
dn2:23.3: This person is made up of the four great elements. When they die, the earth in their body merges and coalesces with the mass of earth. The water in their body merges and coalesces with the mass of water. The fire in their body merges and coalesces with the mass of fire. The air in their body merges and coalesces with the mass of air. The faculties are transferred to space.
dn2:23.4: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.
dn2:23.5: Their footprints show the way to the cemetery.
dn2:23.6: The bones become bleached. Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.
dn2:23.7: Giving is a doctrine of idiots.
dn2:23.8: When anyone affirms a teaching of action and afterlife, it’s just hollow, false nonsense.
dn2:23.9: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and don’t exist after death.’
dn2:24.1: And so, when I asked Ajita of the hair blanket about the fruits of the ascetic life that are presently evident, he answered with the doctrine of annihilationism.
dn2:24.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
dn2:24.5: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
dn2:24.6: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Ajita of the hair blanket.
dn2:24.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
dn2:25.1: One time, Bhante, I approached Pakudha Kaccāyana and exchanged pleasantries with him.
dn2:25.2: When the amicable and cordial talk was over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
dn2:26.2: ‘Great king, these seven masses are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
dn2:26.3: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.
dn2:26.5: The masses of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh.
dn2:26.6: These seven masses are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
dn2:26.7: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.
dn2:26.8: And here there is no-one who kills or who makes others kill; no-one who learns or who educates others; no-one who understands or who helps others understand.
dn2:26.9: If you chop off someone’s head with a sharp sword, you don’t take anyone’s life.
dn2:26.10: The sword simply passes through the gap between the seven masses.’
dn2:27.1: And so, when I asked Pakudha Kaccāyana about the fruits of the ascetic life that are presently evident, he answered with something else entirely.
dn2:27.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
dn2:27.5: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
dn2:27.6: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Pakudha Kaccāyana.
dn2:27.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
dn2:28.0: 3.5. The Doctrine of the Jain Nāṭaputta
dn2:28.1: One time, Bhante, I approached the Jain Nāṭaputta and exchanged pleasantries with him.
dn2:28.2: When the amicable and cordial talk was over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
dn2:29.2: ‘Great king, consider a Jain who is restrained in the fourfold constraint.
dn2:29.3: And how is a Jain restrained in the fourfold constraint?
dn2:29.4: It’s when a Jain is restrained in all that is to be restrained, is bridled in all that is to be restrained, has shaken off all that is to be restrained, and is curbed in all that is to be restrained.
dn2:29.5: That’s how a Jain is restrained in the fourfold constraint.
dn2:29.6: When a Jain is restrained in the fourfold constraint,
dn2:29.7: they’re called a knotless one who is self-realized, self-controlled, and steadfast.’
dn2:30.1: And so, when I asked the Jain Ñātika about the fruits of the ascetic life that are presently evident, he answered with the fourfold constraint.
dn2:30.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
dn2:30.5: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
dn2:30.6: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the Jain Nāṭaputta.
dn2:30.7: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
dn2:31.1: One time, Bhante, I approached Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta and exchanged pleasantries with him.
dn2:31.2: When the amicable and cordial talk was over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
dn2:32.2: ‘Suppose you were to ask me whether there is another world. If I believed there was, I would say so.
dn2:32.3: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.
dn2:32.4: Suppose you were to ask me whether there is no other world …
dn2:32.5: whether there both is and is not another world …
dn2:32.6: whether there neither is nor is not another world …
dn2:32.7: whether there are beings who are reborn spontaneously …
dn2:32.8: whether there are no beings who are reborn spontaneously …
dn2:32.9: whether there both are and are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …
dn2:32.10: whether there neither are nor are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …
dn2:32.11: whether there is fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
dn2:32.12: whether there is no fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
dn2:32.13: whether there both is and is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
dn2:32.14: whether there neither is nor is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
dn2:32.15: whether a realized one still exists after death …
dn2:32.16: whether a realized one no longer exists after death …
dn2:32.17: whether a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …
dn2:32.18: whether a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death. If I believed there was, I would say so.
dn2:32.19: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’
dn2:33.1: And so, when I asked Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta about the fruits of the ascetic life that are presently evident, he answered with flip-flopping.
dn2:33.2: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
dn2:33.5: ‘This is the most foolish and muddled of all these ascetics and brahmins!
dn2:33.6: How on earth can he answer with flip-flopping when asked about the fruits of the ascetic life that are presently evident?’
dn2:33.8: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
dn2:33.9: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta.
dn2:33.10: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
dn2:34.0.1: 4. The Fruits of the Ascetic Life
dn2:34.0.2: 4.1. The First Fruit of the Ascetic Life
dn2:34.1: And so I ask the Buddha:
dn2:34.2: Bhante, there are many different professional fields.
dn2:34.3: These include elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and sons of bondservants.
dn2:34.4: They also include bakers, barbers, bathroom attendants, cooks, garland-makers, dyers, weavers, basket-makers, potters, accountants, finger-talliers, or those following any similar professions. All these live off the fruits of their profession which are presently evident.
dn2:34.5: With that they make themselves happy and pleased. They make their parents, their children and partners, and their friends and colleagues happy and pleased. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.
dn2:34.6: Bhante, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise presently evident?”
dn2:34.8: Well then, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
dn2:35.1: What do you think, great king?
dn2:35.2: Suppose you had a man who was a bondservant, a worker. He gets up before you and goes to bed after you, and is obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, and gazing up at your face.
dn2:35.4: ‘The outcome and result of good deeds is so incredible, so amazing!
dn2:35.5: For this King Ajātasattu is a human being, and so am I.
dn2:35.6: Yet he amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five strands of sensuality as if he were a god.
dn2:35.7: Whereas I’m his bondservant, his worker. I get up before him and go to bed after him, and am obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, and gazing up at his face.
dn2:35.8: I really should do good deeds.
dn2:35.9: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
dn2:35.10: After some time, that is what he does.
dn2:35.11: Having gone forth he’d live restrained in body, speech, and thought, living content with nothing more than food and clothes, delighting in seclusion.
dn2:35.12: And suppose your men were to report all this to you.
dn2:35.17: ‘Bring that man to me! Let him once more be my bondservant, my worker’?”
dn2:36.2: Rather, I would bow to him, rise in his presence, and offer him a seat. I’d invite him to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize his lawful guarding and protection.”
dn2:36.4: If this is so, is there a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident or not?”
dn2:36.6: “This is the first fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident, which I point out to you.”
dn2:37.0: 4.2. The Second Fruit of the Ascetic Life
dn2:37.1: “But, Bhante, can you point out another fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise presently evident?”
dn2:37.3: Well then, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
dn2:37.4: What do you think, great king?
dn2:37.5: Suppose you had a man who was a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up his capital.
dn2:37.7: ‘The outcome and result of good deeds is just so incredible, so amazing!
dn2:37.8: For this King Ajātasattu is a human being, and so am I.
dn2:37.9: Yet he amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five strands of sensuality as if he were a god.
dn2:37.10: Whereas I’m a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up his capital.
dn2:37.11: I really should do good deeds.
dn2:37.12: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
dn2:37.13: After some time, he gives up a large or small fortune and a large or small family circle. He shaves off hair and beard, dresses in ocher robes, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn2:37.14: Having gone forth he’d live restrained in body, speech, and thought, living content with nothing more than food and clothes, delighting in seclusion.
dn2:37.15: And suppose your men were to report all this to you.
dn2:37.20: ‘Bring that man to me! Let him once more be a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital’?”
dn2:38.2: Rather, I would bow to him, rise in his presence, and offer him a seat. I’d invite him to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize his lawful guarding and protection.”
dn2:38.4: If this is so, is there a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident or not?”
dn2:38.6: “This is the second fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident, which I point out to you.”
dn2:39.0: 4.3. The Finer Fruits of the Ascetic Life
dn2:39.1: “But, Bhante, can you point out another fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise presently evident?”
dn2:39.3: Well then, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
dn2:40.1: “Consider when a Realized One arises in the world, an Arahant, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
dn2:40.2: Having for himself comprehended and experienced this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—he makes it known to others.
dn2:40.3: He teaches a Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a renunciate life that’s entirely complete and pure.
dn2:41.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s son, or someone born in some good family.
dn2:41.2: He gains faith in the Realized One
dn2:41.4: ‘Household life is confined and dusty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.
dn2:41.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the renunciate life utterly complete and pure, like a polished shell.
dn2:41.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
dn2:41.7: After some time he gives up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. He shaves off hair and beard, dresses in ocher robes, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn2:42.1: Once he’s gone forth, he lives restrained by the code of conduct, endowed with proper behavior and a suitable environment. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, he trains in the training rules. He acts skillfully by body and speech. He’s purified in livelihood and accomplished in virtue. He guards the sense doors, is endowed with recollection-and-awareness, and is content.
dn2:43.1: And how, great king, is the bhikkhu accomplished in virtue?
dn2:43.2: It’s when the bhikkhu gives up and abstains from killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. He’s scrupulous and kind, living compassionate for the welfare of all creatures and beings.
dn2:43.4: He gives up and abstains from taking what is not given. He takes only what’s given, and expects only what’s given. He keeps himself clean by not thieving.
dn2:43.6: He gives up and abstains from incelibacy. He is celibate, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
dn2:44.1: He gives up and abstains from lying. He speaks the truth and sticks to the truth. He’s honest and trustworthy, and doesn’t trick the world with his words.
dn2:44.3: He gives up and abstains from divisive speech. He doesn’t repeat in one place what he heard in another to divide people against each other. Instead, he reconciles those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, enjoying harmony, and speaking words that promote harmony.
dn2:44.5: He gives up and abstains from harsh speech. He speaks in a way that’s gentle, pleasing to the ear, affectionate, going to the heart, polite, likable, and agreeable to the people.
dn2:44.7: He gives up and abstains from frivolous speech. His words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching-and-discipline. He says things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
dn2:45.1: He abstains from violence towards plants and seeds.
dn2:45.2: He eats in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and at the wrong time.
dn2:45.3: He abstains from dancing, singing, music, and watching shows.
dn2:45.4: He avoids beautifying and adorning himself with garlands, perfumes, and makeup.
dn2:45.5: He avoids high and luxurious beds.
dn2:45.6: He abstains from receiving gold and money,
dn2:45.15: He abstains from running errands and messages;
dn2:45.19: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
dn2:45.21: (The shorter section on virtue is finished).
dn2:46.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in injuring plants and seeds.
dn2:46.2: These include plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth. He abstains from such injury to plants and seeds.
dn2:47.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in storing up goods for their own use.
dn2:47.2: This includes such things as food, drink, clothes, vehicles, bedding, fragrance, and material things.
dn2:47.3: He abstains from storing up such goods.
dn2:48.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in seeing shows.
dn2:48.2: This includes such things as dancing, singing, music, performances, and storytelling; clapping, gongs, and kettledrums; beauty pageants; acrobatic and bone-washing displays of the corpse-workers; battles of elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, goats, rams, chickens, and quails; staff-fights, boxing, and wrestling; combat, roll calls of the armed forces, battle-formations, and regimental reviews.
dn2:48.3: He abstains from seeing such shows.
dn2:49.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in gambling that causes negligence.
dn2:49.2: This includes such things as checkers with eight or ten rows, checkers in the air, hopscotch, spillikins, board-games, tip-cat, drawing straws, dice, leaf-flutes, toy plows, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, toy bows, guessing words from syllables, guessing another’s thoughts, and imitating musical instruments.
dn2:50.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still make use of high and luxurious bedding.
dn2:50.2: This includes such things as sofas, couches, woolen covers—shag-piled, colorful, white, embroidered with flowers, quilted, embroidered with animals, double-or single-fringed—and silk covers studded with gems, as well as silken sheets, woven carpets, rugs for elephants, horses, or chariots, antelope hide rugs, and spreads of fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red cushions at both ends.
dn2:51.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
dn2:51.2: This includes such things as applying beauty products by anointing, massaging, bathing, and rubbing; mirrors, ointments, garlands, fragrances, and makeup; face-powder, foundation, bracelets, headbands, fancy walking-sticks or containers, rapiers, parasols, fancy sandals, turbans, jewelry, chowries, and long-fringed white robes.
dn2:51.3: He abstains from such beautification and adornment.
dn2:52.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in low talk.
dn2:52.2: This includes such topics as talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
dn2:52.3: They refrain from such low talk.
dn2:53.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in arguments.
dn2:53.2: They say such things as: ‘You don’t understand this teaching-and-discipline. I understand this teaching-and-discipline. What, you understand this teaching-and-discipline? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!’
dn2:53.3: They refrain from such argumentative talk.
dn2:54.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in running errands and messages.
dn2:54.2: This includes running errands for rulers, ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or princes who say: ‘Go here, go there. Take this, bring that from there.’
dn2:54.3: He abstains from running such errands.
dn2:55.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in deceit, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material possessions to chase after other material possessions. He abstains from such deceit and flattery.
dn2:55.3: The middle section on virtue is finished.
dn2:56.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low arts, by wrong livelihood.
dn2:56.2: This includes such fields as limb-reading, omenology, divining celestial portents, interpreting dreams, divining bodily marks, divining holes in cloth gnawed by mice, fire offerings, ladle offerings, offerings of husks, rice powder, rice, ghee, or oil; offerings from the mouth, blood sacrifices, palmistry; geomancy for building sites, fields, and cemeteries; exorcisms, earth magic, snake charming, poisons; the lore of the scorpion, the rat, the bird, and the crow; prophesying life span, chanting protective charms, and divining omens from wild animals.
dn2:56.3: He abstains from such low arts, such wrong livelihood.
dn2:57.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low arts, by wrong livelihood.
dn2:57.2: This includes reading the marks of gems, cloth, clubs, swords, spears, arrows, weapons, women, men, boys, girls, male and female bondservants, elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, cows, goats, rams, chickens, quails, monitor lizards, rabbits, tortoises, or deer.
dn2:57.3: He abstains from such low arts, such wrong livelihood.
dn2:58.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low arts, by wrong livelihood.
dn2:58.2: This includes making predictions that the king will march forth or march back; or that our king will attack and the enemy king will retreat, or vice versa; or that our king will triumph and the enemy king will be defeated, or vice versa; and so there will be victory for one and defeat for the other.
dn2:58.3: He abstains from such low arts, such wrong livelihood.
dn2:59.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low arts, by wrong livelihood.
dn2:59.2: This includes making predictions that there will be an eclipse of the moon, or sun, or stars; that the sun, moon, and stars will be in conjunction or in opposition; that there will be a meteor shower, a fiery sky, an earthquake, thunder; that there will be a rising, a setting, a darkening, a brightening of the moon, sun, and stars. And it also includes making predictions about the results of all such phenomena.
dn2:59.3: He abstains from such low arts, such wrong livelihood.
dn2:60.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low arts, by wrong livelihood.
dn2:60.2: This includes predicting whether there will be plenty of rain or drought; plenty to eat or famine; an abundant harvest or a bad harvest; security or peril; sickness or health. It also includes such occupations as arithmetic, accounting, calculating, poetry, and cosmology.
dn2:60.3: He abstains from such low arts, such wrong livelihood.
dn2:61.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low arts, by wrong livelihood.
dn2:61.2: This includes making arrangements for giving and taking in marriage; for engagement and divorce; and for scattering rice inwards or outwards at the wedding ceremony. It also includes casting spells for good or bad luck, treating impacted fetuses, binding the tongue, or locking the jaws; charms for the hands and ears; questioning a mirror, a girl, or a god as an oracle; worshiping the sun, worshiping the Great One, breathing fire, and invoking Siri, the goddess of luck.
dn2:61.3: He abstains from such low arts, such wrong livelihood.
dn2:62.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low arts, by wrong livelihood.
dn2:62.2: This includes rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving rinsing and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and binding on herbs.
dn2:62.3: He abstains from such low arts, such wrong livelihood.
dn2:63.1: A bhikkhu thus accomplished in virtue sees no danger in any quarter in regards to his virtuous restraint.
dn2:63.2: It’s like a king who has defeated his enemies. He sees no danger from his foes in any quarter.
dn2:63.3: In the same way, a bhikkhu thus accomplished in virtue sees no danger in any quarter in regards to his virtuous restraint.
dn2:63.4: Endowed with this noble aggregate of virtue, he experiences a blameless ease internally.
dn2:63.5: That’s how the bhikkhu is accomplished in virtue.
dn2:63.6: (The longer section on virtue is finished).
dn2:64.1: And how does the bhikkhu guard the sense doors?
dn2:64.2: When he sees a sight with the eye, he doesn’t grasp at signs and features of it
dn2:64.3: on account of which—due to abiding with the eye faculty unrestrained—bad, detrimental phenomena of longing and upset would flow in on him. He practices to restrain that; he guards the eye faculty and brings about the restraint of the eye faculty.
dn2:64.4: When he hears a sound with the ear …
dn2:64.5: When he smells an odor with the nose …
dn2:64.6: When he tastes a flavor with the tongue …
dn2:64.7: When he touches a touch with the body …
dn2:64.8: When he cognizes a phenomenon with the mental faculty, he doesn’t grasp at signs and features of it
dn2:64.9: on account of which—due to abiding with the mental faculty unrestrained—bad, detrimental phenomena of longing and upset would flow in on him. He practices to restrain that; he guards the mental faculty and brings about the restraint of the mental faculty.
dn2:64.10: Possessed of this noble sense restraint, he experiences an unsullied ease internally.
dn2:64.11: That’s how the bhikkhu guards the sense doors.
dn2:65.1: And how is the bhikkhu possessed of recollection-and-awareness?
dn2:65.2: He acts with awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
dn2:65.3: That’s how the bhikkhu is possessed of recollection-and-awareness.
dn2:66.1: And how is the bhikkhu content?
dn2:66.2: It’s when the bhikkhu is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever he goes, he sets out taking only these things.
dn2:66.3: He’s like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
dn2:66.4: In the same way, the bhikkhu is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever he goes, he sets out taking only these things.
dn2:66.5: That’s how the bhikkhu is content.
dn2:67.1: Possessed of noble aggregate of noble virtue, this noble sense restraint, this noble recollection-and-awareness, and this noble contentment,
dn2:67.2: he frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
dn2:67.3: After the meal, he returns from almsround, sits down cross-legged, sets his body straight, and establishes recollection at the fore.
dn2:68.1: Giving up longing in regard to the world, he abides with a mind rid of longing; he cleanses the mind of longing.
dn2:68.2: Giving up ill will and hatred, he abides with a mind rid of ill will, compassionate for the welfare of all creatures and beings; he cleanses the mind of ill will and hatred.
dn2:68.3: Giving up indolence-and-lethargy, he abides with a mind rid of indolence-and-lethargy, perceiving light, recollected, and aware; he cleanses the mind of indolence-and-lethargy.
dn2:68.4: Giving up restlessness-and-anxiety, he abides without restlessness, his mind internally appeased; he cleanses the mind of restlessness-and-anxiety.
dn2:68.5: Giving up doubt, he abides having gone beyond doubt, not uncertain about beneficial qualities; he cleanses the mind of doubt.
dn2:69.1: Suppose a man who has gotten into debt were to apply himself to work,
dn2:69.3: He would pay off the original loan and have enough left over to support his partner.
dn2:69.8: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn2:70.1: Suppose there was a man who was sick, suffering, gravely ill. He’d lose his appetite and get physically weak.
dn2:70.2: But after some time he’d recover from that illness, and regain his appetite and their strength.
dn2:70.8: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn2:71.1: Suppose a man was imprisoned in a jail.
dn2:71.2: But after some time he was released from jail, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth.
dn2:71.6: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn2:72.1: Suppose a man was a bondservant. He would not be his own master, but indentured to another, unable to go where he wishes.
dn2:72.2: But after some time he’d be freed from servitude. He would be his own master, not indentured to another, an emancipated individual able to go where he wishes.
dn2:72.6: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn2:73.1: Suppose there was a man with wealth and property who was traveling along a desert road, which was perilous, with nothing to eat.
dn2:73.2: But after some time he crossed over the desert safely, arriving within a village, a sanctuary free of peril.
dn2:73.6: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn2:74.1: In the same way, the bhikkhu regards these five hindrances that are not given up in him as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.
dn2:74.2: But when these five hindrances are given up in him, the bhikkhu regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and a place of safety at last.
dn2:74.4: Considering that the five hindrances have been given up in him, gladness is born. When he’s glad, joy is born. When the mind is joyous, the body becomes calm. When the body is calm, he feels at ease. When he’s at ease, the mind becomes composed.
dn2:75.1: Quite disjoined from sensuality, disjoined from detrimental phenomena, with thinking and with pondering, with joy and ease born of separation, he abides having entered upon the first jhāna.
dn2:75.2: He tops up, suffuses, fills, and pervades his body with the joy and ease born of separation. There would be no part of his whole body that’s not pervaded with the joy and ease born of separation.
dn2:76.1: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
dn2:76.2: In the same way, the bhikkhu tops up, suffuses, fills, and pervades his body with the joy and ease born of separation. There would be no part of his whole body that’s not pervaded with the joy and ease born of separation.
dn2:76.3: This, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:77.1: Furthermore, with the appeasement of thinking and pondering, with internal confidence and collectedness of mind, without thinking or pondering and with joy and ease born of composure, the bhikkhu abides having entered upon the second jhāna.
dn2:77.2: He tops up, suffuses, fills, and pervades his body with the joy and ease born of composure. There would be no part of his whole body that’s not pervaded with the joy and ease born of composure.
dn2:78.1: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water where there would be no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and no rainfall to replenish it from time to time.
dn2:78.2: But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake would top up, suffuse, fill, and pervade the lake. There would be no part of the whole lake that’s not pervaded with cool water.
dn2:78.3: In the same way, the bhikkhu tops up, suffuses, fills, and pervades his body with joy and ease born of composure. There would be no part of his whole body that’s not pervaded with the joy and ease born of composure.
dn2:78.4: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:79.1: Furthermore, with the fading of joy, the bhikkhu abides equanimous, recollected, and aware, experiencing ease with the body. He abides having entered upon the third jhāna, with regard to which the noble ones say “one abides equanimous, recollected, and at ease.”
dn2:79.2: He tops up, suffuses, fills, and pervades his body with the ease devoid of joy. There would be no part of his whole body that’s not pervaded with the ease devoid of joy.
dn2:80.1: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re topped up, suffused, filled, and pervaded with cool water. There would be no part of them that’s not pervaded with cool water.
dn2:80.2: In the same way, the bhikkhu tops up, suffuses, fills, and pervades his whole body with the ease devoid of joy. There would be no part of his whole body that’s not pervaded with the ease devoid of joy.
dn2:80.3: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:81.1: Furthermore, with the giving up of ease and unease—and with the ending of joys and upsets beforehand—without ease or unease, with purity of equanimity and recollection, the bhikkhu abides having entered upon the fourth jhāna.
dn2:81.2: He sits having pervaded his body with a pure, bright mind. There would be no part of his whole body that’s not pervaded with a pure, bright mind.
dn2:82.1: It’s like a man sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There would be no part of his whole body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
dn2:82.2: In the same way, the bhikkhu sits having pervaded his body with a pure, bright mind. There would be no part of his whole body that’s not pervaded with a pure, bright mind.
dn2:82.3: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:83.1: When his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards knowledge-and-vision.
dn2:83.3: ‘This body of mine is material. It’s made up of the four great elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
dn2:83.4: And this consciousness of mine is dependent and tied to it.’
dn2:84.1: Suppose there was a beryl gem that was beautiful, genuine, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities.
dn2:84.2: And it was strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.
dn2:84.3: And a man with good eyesight were to take it in his hand and check it:
dn2:84.4: ‘This beryl gem is beautiful, genuine, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities.
dn2:84.5: And it’s strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.’
dn2:84.6: In the same way, when his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards knowledge-and-vision.
dn2:84.10: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:85.1: When his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards the creation of a mind-made body.
dn2:85.2: From this body he creates another body, material, mind-made, complete in all its various parts, not deficient in any faculty.
dn2:86.1: Suppose a man was to draw a reed out from its sheath.
dn2:86.3: ‘This is the reed, this is the sheath. The reed and the sheath are different things. The reed has been drawn out from the sheath.’
dn2:86.4: Or suppose a man was to draw a sword out from its scabbard.
dn2:86.6: ‘This is the sword, this is the scabbard. The sword and the scabbard are different things. The sword has been drawn out from the scabbard.’
dn2:86.7: Or suppose a man was to draw a snake out from its slough.
dn2:86.9: ‘This is the snake, this is the slough. The snake and the slough are different things. The snake has been drawn out from the slough.’
dn2:86.10: In the same way, when his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards the creation of a mind-made body.
dn2:86.11: From this body he creates another body, material, mind-made, complete in all its various parts, not deficient in any faculty.
dn2:86.12: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:87.1: When his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it extends it towards the various kinds of psychic abilities.
dn2:87.2: He wields the many kinds of psychic ability: multiplying himself and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unimpeded through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.
dn2:88.1: Suppose a deft potter or his apprentice had some well-prepared clay. He could produce any kind of pot that he likes.
dn2:88.2: Or suppose a deft ivory-carver or his apprentice had some well-prepared ivory. He could produce any kind of ivory item that he likes.
dn2:88.3: Or suppose a deft goldsmith or his apprentice had some well-prepared gold. He could produce any kind of gold item that he likes.
dn2:88.4: In the same way, when his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards the many kinds of psychic abilities.
dn2:88.6: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:89.1: When his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards the divine ear.
dn2:89.2: With the divine ear element that is purified and superhuman, he hears both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.
dn2:90.1: Suppose there was a man traveling along the road. He’d hear the sound of drums, clay drums, horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms. He’d think: ‘That’s the sound of drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of clay drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms.’
dn2:90.2: In the same way, when his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards the divine ear.
dn2:90.3: With the divine ear element that is purified and superhuman, he hears both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.
dn2:90.4: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:91.1: When his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards the knowledge of comprehension of minds.
dn2:91.2: He understands the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with his own mind.
dn2:91.3: He understands mind with passion as ‘mind with passion,’
dn2:91.4: and mind without passion as ‘mind without passion.’
dn2:91.5: He understands mind with aversion as ‘mind with aversion,’
dn2:91.6: and mind without aversion as ‘mind without aversion.’
dn2:91.7: He understands mind with muddledness as ‘mind with muddledness,’
dn2:91.8: and mind without muddledness as ‘mind without muddledness.’
dn2:91.17: He understands liberated mind as ‘liberated mind,’
dn2:92.1: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they’d check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they had a spot they’d know ‘I have a spot,’ and if they had no spots they’d know ‘I have no spots.’
dn2:92.2: In the same way, when his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards the knowledge of comprehension of minds.
dn2:92.3: He understands the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with his own mind.
dn2:92.20: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:93.1: When his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he extends it towards the knowledge of recollecting past lives.
dn2:93.2: He recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand births; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. I remembered: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and displeasure, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I reappeared somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and displeasure, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I reappeared here.’ And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
dn2:94.1: Suppose a man was to leave his home village and go to another village. From that village he’d go to yet another village. And from that village he’d return to their his village. He’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’
dn2:94.2: In the same way, when his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards the knowledge of recollecting past lives.
dn2:94.4: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:95.1: When his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs it and extends it towards the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.
dn2:95.2: With the divine eye that is purified and superhuman, he sees beings passing away and reappearing—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how beings reappear according to their actions. ‘These beings engaged in misconduct by way of body, speech, and thought. They found fault with the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they reappear in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These beings, however, engaged in good conduct by way of body, speech, and thought. They did not find fault with the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they reappear in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with the divine eye that is purified and superhuman, he sees beings passing away and reappearing—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how beings reappear according to their actions.
dn2:96.1: Suppose there was a stilt longhouse at the central square. A man with good eyesight standing there might see people entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square. He’d think: ‘These are people entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square.’
dn2:96.2: In the same way, when his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs it and extends it towards the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.
dn2:96.4: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:97.1: When his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he extends it towards the knowledge of the destruction of the influxes.
dn2:97.2: He understands as it is: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
dn2:97.3: He understands as it is: ‘These are influxes’ … ‘This is the origin of influxes’ … ‘This is the cessation of influxes’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of influxes.’
dn2:97.4: Knowing and seeing like this, his mind is liberated from the influxes of sensuality, being, and ignorance.
dn2:97.5: When it’s liberated, he knows it’s liberated.
dn2:97.6: He understands: ‘Birth is exhausted, the renunciate life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there will be no more of this.’
dn2:98.1: Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A man with good eyesight standing on the bank would see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still. He’d think: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’
dn2:98.2: In the same way, when his mind has become composed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he directs and extends it towards the knowledge of the destruction of the influxes.
dn2:98.8: This too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than the former ones.
dn2:98.9: And, great king, there is no other fruit of the ascetic life that’s presently evident which is better and finer than this.”
dn2:99.0: 5. Ajātasattu Declares Himself a Lay Follower
dn2:99.1: When the Buddha had spoken, King Ajātasattu said to him,
dn2:99.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
dn2:99.4: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the Dhamma, and to the Saṅgha of bhikkhus.
dn2:99.5: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
dn2:99.6: I have made a mistake, Bhante. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to take the life of my father, a just and principled king, for the sake of power.
dn2:99.7: Please, Bhante, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
dn2:100.1: “Indeed, great king, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to take the life of your father, a just and principled king.
dn2:100.2: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
dn2:100.3: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”
dn2:101.1: When the Buddha had spoken, King Ajātasattu said to him,
dn2:101.2: “Well, now, Bhante, I must go. I have many duties, and much to do.”
dn2:101.4: Then the king, having delighted in and expressed appreciation for what the Buddha said, got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled him, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
dn2:102.1: Soon after the king had left, the Buddha addressed the bhikkhus,
dn2:102.4: If he had not taken the life of his father, a just and principled king, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma would have arisen in him in that very seat.”
dn2:102.5: That is what the Buddha said.
dn2:102.6: Pleased, the bhikkhus delighted in what the Buddha said.
